QC.Acc01.description: Is the source code managed with a Version Control System?
QC.Acc01.hint: The source code shall be managed with Git and remain publicly available for this criterion to be successful. Please check Pro Git docs about how to get started using Git tool. Guidelines provided by the most popular social coding platforms (GitHub, GitLab) are also a good starting point

evidence.message: Source code uses Git for version control

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc06.1.description: Is the software scope outlined in the code repository?
QC.Doc06.1.hint: A README file presents your software to the audience interested in your software project. Several online sites simplify the task of creating the README file, such as Make a README or readme.so sites. Be sure to add it to the code repository's root path

evidence.message: A README file is present in the code repository

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc06.3.description: Does the project establish a code of conduct for its participants?
QC.Doc06.3.hint: A CODE_OF_CONDUCT file sets the path for a constructive, respectful and positive atmosphere among all the contributors in your software project. Of course you can define your own, but in case you want to rely on external and widely-adopted code of conducts check out some of the most popular ones: Contributor Covenant or Citizen Code of Conduct

evidence.message: A CODE_OF_CONDUCT file is present in the code repository

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc06.2.description: Is there a clear path or guidelines on how to contribute to the code?
QC.Doc06.2.hint: A CONTRIBUTING file shall be present in the root path of the code repository describing the expected workflow to follow when adding contributions. Please check Mozilla's guidelines and GitHub's CONTRIBUTING.md example to get inspired on how to write a good CONTRIBUTING file

evidence.message: A CONTRIBUTING file is present in the code repository

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc01.1.description: Are docs managed in the same repository as code?
QC.Doc01.1.hint: This subcriterion will succeed if the documentation files exist on the same repository as the source code, e.g. under a docs/ folder

evidence.message: Documentation resides in the same repository as code

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc02.X.description: Are docs following a style for the Markdown markup language?
QC.Doc02.X.hint: When using a docs-as-code approach, the style of the markup language is being checked. SQAaaS relies on markdownlint for Markdown files and restructuredtext-lint for reStructuredText

evidence.message: Docs are not fully compliant with markdownlint standard

.. code-block:: yaml
   :caption: ``slurm_config.yaml``
   :name: Example SLURM Config

    account: intertwin
    time: 01:00:00
    partition: develbooster

    # Which distributed strategy/framework to use, controlling how the communication
    # between workers is implemented. The acronym 'ddp' refers to PyTorch's Distributed
    # Data Parallel.
    dist_strat: ddp # "ddp", "deepspeed" or "horovod"

    std_out: slurm_job_logs/${dist_strat}.out
    err_out: slurm_job_logs/${dist_strat}.err
    job_name: ${dist_strat}-job

    num_nodes: 1
    num_tasks_per_node: 1
    gpus_per_node: 4
    cpus_per_task: 16

    training_cmd: "train.py"

.. code-block:: bash
   :caption: ``ddp-1x4.sh``
   :name: SLURM Job Script generated using the configuration above

      #!/bin/bash

      # Job configuration
      #SBATCH --job-name=ddp-job
      #SBATCH --account=intertwin
      #SBATCH --partition=develbooster
      #SBATCH --time=01:00:00

      #SBATCH --output=slurm_job_logs/ddp.out
      #SBATCH --error=slurm_job_logs/ddp.err

      # Resource allocation
      #SBATCH --nodes=1
      #SBATCH --ntasks-per-node=1
      #SBATCH --cpus-per-task=16
      #SBATCH --gpus-per-node=4
      #SBATCH --gres=gpu:4
      #SBATCH --exclusive

      # Pre-execution command
      ml --force purge
      ml Stages/2025 GCC OpenMPI CUDA/12 cuDNN MPI-settings/CUDA Python CMake HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py git
      source .venv/bin/activate
      export OMP_NUM_THREADS=4

      # Job execution command
      srun --cpu-bind=none --ntasks-per-node=1 \
      bash -c "torchrun \
      --log_dir='logs_torchrun' \
      --nnodes=$SLURM_NNODES \
      --nproc_per_node=$SLURM_GPUS_PER_NODE \
      --rdzv_id=$SLURM_JOB_ID \
      --rdzv_conf=is_host=\$(((SLURM_NODEID)) && echo 0 || echo 1) \
      --rdzv_backend=c10d \
      --rdzv_endpoint='$(scontrol show hostnames "$SLURM_JOB_NODELIST" | head -n 1)'i:29500 \
      train.py""}, {"line": 11, "source": "./docs/how-it-works/loggers/explain_loggers.rst", "level": 3, "type": "ERROR", "message": "Unknown interpreted text role "class".", "full_message": "Unknown interpreted text role "class"."}, {"line": 22, "source": "./docs/how-it-works/loggers/explain_loggers.rst", "level": 3, "type": "ERROR", "message": "Unknown interpreted text role "numref".", "full_message": "Unknown interpreted text role "numref"."}, {"line": 22, "source": "./docs/how-it-works/loggers/explain_loggers.rst", "level": 3, "type": "ERROR", "message": "Unknown interpreted text role "py:mod".", "full_message": "Unknown interpreted text role "py:mod"."}, {"line": 42, "source": "./docs/how-it-works/loggers/explain_loggers.rst", "level": 3, "type": "ERROR", "message": "Unknown interpreted text role "class".", "full_message": "Unknown interpreted text role "class"."}, {"line": 42, "source": "./docs/how-it-works/loggers/explain_loggers.rst", "level": 3, "type": "ERROR", "message": "Unknown interpreted text role "meth".", "full_message": "Unknown interpreted text role "meth"."}, {"line": 42, "source": "./docs/how-it-works/loggers/explain_loggers.rst", "level": 3, "type": "ERROR", "message": "Unknown interpreted text role "py:mod".", "full_message": "Unknown interpreted text role "py:mod"."}, {"line": 54, "source": "./docs/how-it-works/loggers/explain_loggers.rst", "level": 2, "type": "WARNING", "message": "Cannot analyze code.         system at Juelich Supercomputer (JSC):

        .. tab-set::

            .. tab-item:: PyTorch

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml Stages/2025 GCC OpenMPI CUDA/12 cuDNN MPI-settings/CUDA
                    ml Python CMake HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py git

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here

            .. tab-item:: TensorFlow

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml Stages/2024 GCC/12.3.0 OpenMPI CUDA/12 MPI-settings/CUDA
                    ml Python/3.11 HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py CMake cuDNN/8.9.5.29-CUDA-12

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here

    .. tab-item:: Vega

        Modules for `Vega <https://doc.vega.izum.si/introduction/>`_ Supercomputer:

        .. tab-set::

            .. tab-item:: PyTorch

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml CMake/3.29.3-GCCcore-13.3.0
                    ml mpi4py/3.1.5
                    ml OpenMPI/4.1.6-GCC-13.2.0
                    ml cuDNN/8.9.7.29-CUDA-12.3.0
                    ml CUDA/12.6.0
                    ml NCCL/2.22.3-GCCcore-13.3.0-CUDA-12.6.0
                    ml Python/3.12.3-GCCcore-13.3.0

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here


            .. tab-item:: TensorFlow

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml CMake/3.29.3-GCCcore-13.3.0

    .. tab-item:: LUMI

        On `LUMI <https://docs.lumi-supercomputer.eu/hardware/lumig/>`_, Python virtual
        environments are discouraged in favour of containers. Load the following modules before
        running commands in your AI containers:

            .. code-block:: bash

                ml --force purge
                ml LUMI partition/G
                module use /appl/local/containers/ai-modules
                module load singularity-AI-bindings

        These modules are needed to bind into the container the correct software suite on LUMI.
        More info can be found `here <https://lumi-supercomputer.github.io/LUMI-training-materials/ai-20250204/extra_05_RunningContainers/>`_.

.. tab-set::

    .. tab-item:: Local (CPU)

        .. code-block:: bash

            uv sync --extra torch --extra dev

            # Or alternatively, using pip
            uv pip install -e ".[torch,dev]"


    .. tab-item:: Local (CUDA)

        .. code-block:: bash

            uv sync --extra torch --extra dev

            # Or alternatively, using pip
            uv pip install -e ".[torch,dev]" \
                --extra-index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu121


    .. tab-item:: HPC (CUDA)

        Note: This is the same as ``Local (CUDA)`` but without using the cache directory.

        .. code-block:: bash

            uv sync --extra torch --extra dev

            # Or alternatively, using pip
            uv pip install -e ".[torch,dev]" \
                --no-cache-dir \
                --extra-index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu121

    account: intertwin
    time: 01:00:00

    # Which distributed strategy/framework to use, controlling how the communication

    dist_strat: ddp # "ddp", "deepspeed" or "horovod"

    err_out: slurm_job_logs/${dist_strat}.err

      #!/bin/bash

      # Job configuration
      #SBATCH --job-name=ddp-job
      #SBATCH --account=intertwin
      #SBATCH --partition=develbooster
      #SBATCH --time=01:00:00

      #SBATCH --output=slurm_job_logs/ddp.out
      #SBATCH --error=slurm_job_logs/ddp.err

      # Resource allocation
      #SBATCH --nodes=1
      #SBATCH --ntasks-per-node=1
      #SBATCH --cpus-per-task=16
      #SBATCH --gpus-per-node=4
      #SBATCH --gres=gpu:4
      #SBATCH --exclusive

      # Pre-execution command
      ml --force purge
      ml Stages/2025 GCC OpenMPI CUDA/12 cuDNN MPI-settings/CUDA Python CMake HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py git
      source .venv/bin/activate
      export OMP_NUM_THREADS=4

      # Job execution command
      srun --cpu-bind=none --ntasks-per-node=1 \
      bash -c "torchrun \
      --log_dir='logs_torchrun' \
      --nnodes=$SLURM_NNODES \
      --nproc_per_node=$SLURM_GPUS_PER_NODE \
      --rdzv_id=$SLURM_JOB_ID \
      --rdzv_conf=is_host=\$(((SLURM_NODEID)) && echo 0 || echo 1) \
      --rdzv_backend=c10d \
      --rdzv_endpoint='$(scontrol show hostnames "$SLURM_JOB_NODELIST" | head -n 1)'i:29500 \
      train.py"

                    ml --force purge
                    ml Stages/2025 GCC OpenMPI CUDA/12 cuDNN MPI-settings/CUDA
                    ml Python CMake HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py git

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here

            .. tab-item:: TensorFlow

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml Stages/2024 GCC/12.3.0 OpenMPI CUDA/12 MPI-settings/CUDA
                    ml Python/3.11 HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py CMake cuDNN/8.9.5.29-CUDA-12

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here

        Modules for `Vega <https://doc.vega.izum.si/introduction/>`_ Supercomputer:

        .. tab-set::

            .. tab-item:: PyTorch

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml CMake/3.29.3-GCCcore-13.3.0
                    ml mpi4py/3.1.5
                    ml OpenMPI/4.1.6-GCC-13.2.0
                    ml cuDNN/8.9.7.29-CUDA-12.3.0
                    ml CUDA/12.6.0
                    ml NCCL/2.22.3-GCCcore-13.3.0-CUDA-12.6.0
                    ml Python/3.12.3-GCCcore-13.3.0

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here


            .. tab-item:: TensorFlow

                    ml mpi4py/3.1.5
                    ml OpenMPI/4.1.6-GCC-13.2.0

                    ml Python/3.12.3-GCCcore-13.3.0

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here


    .. tab-item:: LUMI

        On `LUMI <https://docs.lumi-supercomputer.eu/hardware/lumig/>`_, Python virtual
        environments are discouraged in favour of containers. Load the following modules before
        running commands in your AI containers:

            .. code-block:: bash

                ml --force purge
                ml LUMI partition/G
                module use /appl/local/containers/ai-modules
                module load singularity-AI-bindings

        These modules are needed to bind into the container the correct software suite on LUMI.
        More info can be found `here <https://lumi-supercomputer.github.io/LUMI-training-materials/ai-20250204/extra_05_RunningContainers/>`_.

            .. code-block:: bash

                ml --force purge
                ml LUMI partition/G
                module use /appl/local/containers/ai-modules
                module load singularity-AI-bindings

        These modules are needed to bind into the container the correct software suite on LUMI.
        More info can be found `here <https://lumi-supercomputer.github.io/LUMI-training-materials/ai-20250204/extra_05_RunningContainers/>`_.

.. tab-set::

    .. tab-item:: Juelich (JSC)

        Modules for the `JUWELS <https://apps.fz-juelich.de/jsc/hps/juwels/configuration.html>`_
        system at Juelich Supercomputer (JSC):

        .. tab-set::

            .. tab-item:: PyTorch

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml Stages/2025 GCC OpenMPI CUDA/12 cuDNN MPI-settings/CUDA
                    ml Python CMake HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py git

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here

            .. tab-item:: TensorFlow

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml Stages/2024 GCC/12.3.0 OpenMPI CUDA/12 MPI-settings/CUDA
                    ml Python/3.11 HDF5 PnetCDF libaio mpi4py CMake cuDNN/8.9.5.29-CUDA-12

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here

    .. tab-item:: Vega

        Modules for `Vega <https://doc.vega.izum.si/introduction/>`_ Supercomputer:

        .. tab-set::

            .. tab-item:: PyTorch

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml CMake/3.29.3-GCCcore-13.3.0
                    ml mpi4py/3.1.5
                    ml OpenMPI/4.1.6-GCC-13.2.0
                    ml cuDNN/8.9.7.29-CUDA-12.3.0
                    ml CUDA/12.6.0
                    ml NCCL/2.22.3-GCCcore-13.3.0-CUDA-12.6.0
                    ml Python/3.12.3-GCCcore-13.3.0

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here


            .. tab-item:: TensorFlow

                .. code-block:: bash

                    ml --force purge
                    ml CMake/3.29.3-GCCcore-13.3.0
                    ml mpi4py/3.1.5
                    ml OpenMPI/4.1.6-GCC-13.2.0
                    ml cuDNN/8.9.7.29-CUDA-12.3.0
                    ml CUDA/12.6.0
                    ml NCCL/2.22.3-GCCcore-13.3.0-CUDA-12.6.0
                    ml Python/3.12.3-GCCcore-13.3.0

                    # Now you can create or active the python environment here


    .. tab-item:: LUMI

        On `LUMI <https://docs.lumi-supercomputer.eu/hardware/lumig/>`_, Python virtual
        environments are discouraged in favour of containers. Load the following modules before
        running commands in your AI containers:

            .. code-block:: bash

                ml --force purge
                ml LUMI partition/G
                module use /appl/local/containers/ai-modules
                module load singularity-AI-bindings

        These modules are needed to bind into the container the correct software suite on LUMI.
        More info can be found `here <https://lumi-supercomputer.github.io/LUMI-training-materials/ai-20250204/extra_05_RunningContainers/>`_.

.. tab-set::

    .. tab-item:: PyTorch

        To install ``itwinai`` with PyTorch without GPU acceleration, you can use the
        following command:

        .. code-block:: bash

            uv pip install "itwinai[torch]"

        To enable GPU acceleration, you can use the following command:

        .. code-block:: bash

            uv pip install ".[torch]" \
                --extra-index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu121


    .. tab-item:: TensorFlow

        To install ``itwinai`` with TensorFlow without GPU acceleration, you can use the
        following command:

        .. code-block:: bash

            uv pip install "itwinai[tf]"

        To enable GPU acceleration, you can use the following command:

        .. code-block:: bash

            uv pip install ".[tf-cuda]"

meta.how: Create a text file (typically named LICENSE or LICENSE.txt) in the root of your source code and copy the text of the license into the file.

conditions.label: License and copyright notice
conditions.description: A copy of the license and copyright notice must be included with the licensed material.

conditions.label: State changes

QC.Lic01.1.description: Is LICENSE file placed in the root path of the code repository?
QC.Lic01.1.hint: Most social coding platforms require the license file to placed in the root path of the code repository, so it is a good practice to use this location by default. Allowed file names are LICENSE, LICENSE.md, LICENSE.rst, LICENSE.txt

meta.description: A permissive license whose main conditions require preservation of copyright and license notices. Contributors provide an express grant of patent rights. Licensed works, modifications, and larger works may be distributed under different terms and without source code.
meta.how: Create a text file (typically named LICENSE or LICENSE.txt) in the root of your source code and copy the text of the license into the file.
meta.note: The Apache Software Foundation recommends taking the additional step of adding a boilerplate notice to the header of each source file. You can find the notice in the appendix at the very end of the license text.

permissions.label: Commercial use
permissions.description: The licensed material and derivatives may be used for commercial purposes.

permissions.label: Modification
permissions.description: The licensed material may be modified.

permissions.label: Distribution
permissions.description: The licensed material may be distributed.

permissions.label: Patent use
permissions.description: This license provides an express grant of patent rights from contributors.

permissions.label: Private use
permissions.description: The licensed material may be used and modified in private.

conditions.label: License and copyright notice
conditions.description: A copy of the license and copyright notice must be included with the licensed material.

conditions.label: State changes
conditions.description: Changes made to the licensed material must be documented.

limitations.label: Trademark use
limitations.description: This license explicitly states that it does NOT grant trademark rights, even though licenses without such a statement probably do not grant any implicit trademark rights.

limitations.label: Liability
limitations.description: This license includes a limitation of liability.

limitations.label: Warranty
limitations.description: This license explicitly states that it does NOT provide any warranty.

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

meta.title: Apache License 2.0
meta.description: A permissive license whose main conditions require preservation of copyright and license notices. Contributors provide an express grant of patent rights. Licensed works, modifications, and larger works may be distributed under different terms and without source code.
meta.how: Create a text file (typically named LICENSE or LICENSE.txt) in the root of your source code and copy the text of the license into the file.
meta.note: The Apache Software Foundation recommends taking the additional step of adding a boilerplate notice to the header of each source file. You can find the notice in the appendix at the very end of the license text.

permissions.label: Commercial use
permissions.description: The licensed material and derivatives may be used for commercial purposes.

permissions.label: Modification
permissions.description: The licensed material may be modified.

permissions.label: Distribution
permissions.description: The licensed material may be distributed.

permissions.label: Patent use
permissions.description: This license provides an express grant of patent rights from contributors.

permissions.label: Private use
permissions.description: The licensed material may be used and modified in private.

conditions.label: License and copyright notice
conditions.description: A copy of the license and copyright notice must be included with the licensed material.

conditions.label: State changes
conditions.description: Changes made to the licensed material must be documented.

limitations.label: Trademark use
limitations.description: This license explicitly states that it does NOT grant trademark rights, even though licenses without such a statement probably do not grant any implicit trademark rights.

limitations.label: Liability
limitations.description: This license includes a limitation of liability.

limitations.label: Warranty
limitations.description: This license explicitly states that it does NOT provide any warranty.

QC.Met01.hint: The two formats for software citation supported by SQAaaS are: 1) CodeMeta and 2) Citation File Format (CFF). While CodeMeta provides you with a more comprehensive description, CFF is a more lightweight, good-enough approach to software (with built-in support by GitHub) citation. Both provide tools (CodeMeta generator, CFFINIT)to easily generate a working citation file. Once having the file, be sure to add it to the root path of your code repo.
